EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



The following provides a brief summary of the key components of the Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program for the aqueous ammonia storage and handling system at Cedar Bayou Electric Generating Station.  



G    ENERAL DESCRIPTION OF THE FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



Cedar Bayou Electric Generating Station (EGS) is located in Eldon, Texas.  The facility is a 2,100-MW nominal electric generation facility with generation capacity provided by two 775-MW gas-fired boilers (Units 1 and 2, with fuel oil firing capability) and a 550-MW combined-cycle unit (Unit 4) arranged in a 2 x 2 x 1 configuration (i.e., two combustion turbines, each equipped with an unfired Heat Recovery Steam Generator (HRSG), with the two HRSG directed to a single steam turbine).  A third gas-fired boiler (Unit 3) was retired in 2007.  Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) systems were retroactively installed on Units 1 and 2, and Unit 4 was equipped with an SCR system at start-up.  The SCRs employ aqueous ammonia injection technology to control emissions of oxides of nitrogen (NOx).  Aqueous ammonia is classified as a toxic chemical subject to the requirements of the RMP Program.  The aqueous ammonia used in these SCR systems is an approximately 30% solution of ammonia in water.



The aqueous ammonia storage and handling system at Cedar Bayou is comprised of storage tanks, transfer pumps, and piping which terminate at the vaporizer for each unit where the aqueous ammonia is atomized and vaporized.  The two tanks each have a capacity of 30,000 gallons, and each tank is equipped with a pressure relief valve, a vacuum breaker valve with flame arrestor, and liquid level indicators.  



All other regulated substances onsite are below applicable thresholds for RMP.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



No accidents have occurred with respect to the aqueous ammonia storage and handling system in the past 5 years.  The SCR system on Unit 2 began service on 2/6/04 and the SCR system on Unit

1 was certified on 6/20/05.  The SCR system on Unit 4 began service in April 2009.  



SUMMARY OF PREVENTION PROGRAM 2



Cedar Bayou is covered by an accidental release prevention program, which includes the following:

?    Periodic hazard review and updates

?    Periodic audits of the system and its operation

?    Emergency response plan coordinated with local responding agencies



The aqueous ammonia storage and handling system prevention program includes the following components:

?    Comprehensive plan covering all components of the aqueous ammonia system with respect to operation, maintenance, inspection, and training

?    Internal compliance audits

?    Incident investigation



SUMMARY OF EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



An emergency response plan for the ammonia storage and handling system has been developed and incorporates elements of the facility?s Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP).  Cedar Bayou employees have been trained in this plan and would be the first responders in the event of an emergency. 



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

A hazard review of the aqueous ammonia storage and handling system at Cedar Bayou was conducted as part of this RMP.  There are no specific changes currently planned to improve safety as the safety program in place is robust and no accidents have occurred.
